Person.Organization: PROVINCIAL HEALTH SERVICES AUTHORITYBRITISH COLUMBIA CANCER AGENCY
UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTRST. JUDE CHILDREN'S RESEARCH HOSPITAL

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: The results published here are in whole or part based upon data generated by the Therapeutically Applicable Research to Generate Effective Treatments (TARGET) initiative, phs000218, managed by the NCI. The data used for this analysis are available [fill in with NCBI dbGaP/SRA and/or NCI GDC/DCC url references]. Information about TARGET can be found at http://ocg.cancer.gov/programs/target.
Policy.ic_specific_access_term: Data for Therapeutically Applicable Research to Generate Effective Treatments (TARGET) are stored within the NCBI database of Genotypes and Phenotypes (dbGaP)/Sequence Read Archive (SRA) or the NCI Genomic Data Commons (GDC) and the TARGET Data Coordinating Center (DCC). Approved users who plan to submit manuscripts using the TARGET pediatric cancer data that would be of comparable scope to the initial TARGET disease-specific comprehensive analysis publication, are expected to abide by TARGET's publication process as outlined on the TARGET Publication Guidelines webpage (http://ocg.cancer.gov/programs/target/target-publication-guidelines). Specifically, comparable scope is defined as global genome-wide analysis of TARGET disease-specific data from one or more than one platform or a trans-TARGET manuscript. Publication involving such analyses is restricted prior to each of the first TARGET disease-specific publications.Approved Users shall reference the TARGET dbGaP accession number: phs000218. If the data is from a single disease studied in TARGET, then the substudy dbGaP accession number is appropriate: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Pilot (ALL P1) – phs000463; Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Expansion (ALL P2) – phs000464; Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) – phs000465; Kidney Tumors: Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney (CCSK) – phs000466; Kidney Tumors: Rhabdoid Tumor (RT) – phs000470; Kidney Tumors: Wilms tumor (WT) – phs000471; Model Systems (MDLS): Cell Lines & Xenografts (including PPTP) – phs000469; Neuroblastoma (NBL) – phs000467; Osteosarcoma (OS) – phs000468. TARGET DCC Version Reference: When data stored at the TARGET Data Coordinating Center (e.g. VCF or MAF sequence files, chip-based data) are used, Approved Users shall reference the version of the TARGET Data Matrix and include “Therapeutically Applicable Research to Generate Effective Treatments Data Matrix. Retrieve Month Day, Year. Website, https://ocg.cancer.gov/programs/target/data-matrix.” Citing TARGET Publications in Manuscripts Using TARGET Data: Additionally, manuscripts using the entire TARGET dataset should cite each of the landscape papers published by TARGET project teams (see list below). For those manuscripts using data from only a single substudy or from a few select substudies, but not the entire TARGET dataset, the investigators should cite the appropriate first paper(s) published for each. *Note: As the remaining substudy project teams publish their first manuscript, the reference to be cited will be added below. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia pilot (ALL P1): Mullighan, C.G., Su, X., Zhang, J., Radtke, I., Phillips, L.A., Miller, C.B., Ma, J., Liu, W., Cheng, C., Schulman, B.A., et al. (2009). Deletion of IKZF1 and prognosis in acute lymphoblastic leukemia. N Engl J Med 360, 470-480. Acute Myeloid Leukemia: Bolouri H, Farrar JE, Triche T Jr, Ries RE, Lim EL, Alonzo TA, Ma Y, Moore R, Mungall AJ, Marra MA et al. (2017). The molecular landscape of pediatric acute myeloid leukemia reveals recurrent structural alterations and age-specific mutational interactions. Nat Med 24(10, 103-112); Neuroblastoma (NBL): Pugh T.J., Morozova O., Attiyeh E.F., Asgharzadeh S., Wei J.S., Auclair D., Carter S.L., Cibulskis K., Hanna M., et al. (2013). The genetic landscape of high-risk neuroblastoma. Nat Genet 45(3):279-84; Wilms tumor: Gadd S, Huff V, Walz AL, Ooms AHAG, Armstrong AE, Gerhard DS, Smith MA, Auvil JMG, Meerzaman D et al. (2017). A Children's Oncology Group and TARGET initiative exploring the genetic landscape of Wilms tumor. Nat Genet 49(10):1487-1494; trans-TARGET: Ma, X., Liu, Y., Liu, Y., Alexandrov, L., Edmonson, M., Gaswad, C., Zhou, X., Li, Y., Rusch, M., Easton, J. et al.(2018). Pan-cancer genome and transcriptome analyses of 1,699 paediatric leukaemias and solid tumours. Nature 555(7696):371-376.

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Unrestricted access (institution responded that the study is not sensitive without submitting a new Institutional Certification)

ConsentGroup.title: Pediatric Cancer Research
ConsentGroup.name: PCR
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use of protected TARGET datasets should be for research projects that can only be conducted using pediatric data (i.e., the research objectives cannot be accomplished using data from adults) and that have likely relevance to developing more effective treatments, diagnostic tests, or prognostic markers for childhood cancers. Applications proposing methods, software, or other tool development would not be considered acceptable uses of the data.

Person.Organization: PROVINCIAL HEALTH SERVICES AUTHORITYBRITISH COLUMBIA CANCER AGENCY
UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTRST. JUDE CHILDREN'S RESEARCH HOSPITAL

The genetic landscape of high-risk neuroblastoma. Nat Genet 45(3):279-84; Wilms tumor: Gadd S, Huff V, Walz AL, Ooms AHAG, Armstrong AE, Gerhard DS, Smith MA, Auvil JMG, Meerzaman D et al. (2017). ConsentGroup.title: Pediatric Cancer Research
ConsentGroup.name: PCR
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use of protected TARGET datasets should be for research projects that can only be conducted using pediatric data (i.e., the research objectives cannot be accomplished using data from adults) and that have likely relevance to developing more effective treatments, diagnostic tests, or prognostic markers for childhood cancers. Applications proposing methods, software, or other tool development would not be considered acceptable uses of the data.

File.filename: Data Use Certification Requirements - TARGET v.2 - Revised 10 20 10.doc

ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use of protected TARGET datasets should be for research projects that can only be conducted using pediatric data (i.e., the research objectives cannot be accomplished using data from adults) and that have likely relevance to developing more effective treatments, diagnostic tests, or prognostic markers for childhood cancers. StudyInfo.Description:
The Therapeutically Applicable Research to Generate Effective Treatments (TARGET) Initiative seeks to accelerate research in novel marker and drug development through identification of genomic changes associated with the following childhood cancers:

  • Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) - A fast-growing type of blood cancer in which too many immature white blood cells are found in the blood and bone marrow.
  • Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) - Another type of blood cancer marked by too many myeloblasts, an alternate type of immature white blood cell, are found in the blood and bone marrow.
  • Neuroblastoma - Cancer of cells of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • Osteosarcoma - A cancer of the bone that primarily affects children and adolescents.
  • Wilms Tumor - A cancer of cells in the kidney that can spread to the liver, lung and lymph nodes.

Together these cancers account for the majority of the more than 10,000 childhood cancer cases diagnosed in the United States each year.

TARGET is employing a set of advanced and complementary analysis technologies to strategically characterize alterations in both gene expression and in genomic structure (such as deletions and amplification) that are involved in childhood cancers. The goal is a comprehensive genomic and transcriptomic profile of each cancer. To learn more about the TARGET project, visit the website at http://target.cancer.gov/.

Integrated analysis of the TARGET data will identify those genes that are either altered in their expression level or mapped to the chromosome regions of deletion/amplification/translocation, as these genes represent strong candidates for therapeutic targeting. Genes of interest identified by TARGET's gene expression and genomic characterization efforts will undergo high-throughput sequencing. The characterization data will be deposited into the TARGET Data Coordinating Center (DCC) database, which is supported by the cancer bioinformatics grid (caBIG), while the sequence data is deposited either into the NCBI's trace repository or the short read archive (SRA).

Participants:

  1. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) - 255 patients (Phase I), Phase II data coming soon
  2. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - data coming soon
  3. Neuroblastoma (NBL) - 448 patients (Phase I), Phase II data coming soon
  4. Osteosarcoma - data coming soon
  5. Wilms tumor - data coming soon
StudyInfo.StudyHistory:
May, 2005 NCI and the American Cancer Society co-sponsor "Childhood Cancer Targeted Therapeutics Workshop" that ultimately served as a basis for the conception of TARGET.
October, 2006 TARGET project officially initiated.
January, 2009 First publication of characterization and analysis of 221 ALL patients.
May, 2009 Follow-up publication of additional genes involved in ALL treatment response.
September, 2009 ARRA funding allows for expansion of TARGET pilot project to include three additional cancers.
